results.title: Among giants
results.creator_credit: Fox Searchlight Pictures, Capitol Films, Kudos, BBC Film Unit, YMPA, Stephen Garrett and Sam Miller
results.brief_description: From the writer of “The Full monty”, Simon Beaufoy, comes “Among giants”, a tale set in Sheffield, England about a group of unemployed blue-collar workers who take on odd jobs to make ends meet. The latest of these high risk ventures is an unofficial contract to paint miles of power towers on the remote and beautiful Yorkshire Moors. The group are an eclectic mix of ageing hippies and adrenalin seeking rock climbers, very laddish in their encounters with one another. Into this all male crew enters Gerry (Rachel Griffiths) a feisty, fearless, mountain climbing Australian backpacker, who upsets the working life and social order of the group. Gerry falls for her boss Ray (Pete Postlethwaite) fuelling problems for both of them with his ex-wife, and with his best friend, Steven. Tensions rise as racing against the clock, the crew strives to complete the job, whilst Ray and Gerry struggle to resolve the status of their relationship. Billed as a romantic comedy, the film is situated in the tradition of light hearted tales of the woes of English working class life.

results.title: American splendor
results.creator_credit: Home Box Office, Fine Line Features, Ted Hope, Robert Pulcini and Shari Springer Berman
results.brief_description: The life and times of American comic book writer Harvey Pekar - meet the real man, and the actor playing him (Paul Giamatti), in a movie about his “ordinary life”. Based on Harvey’s comic book “American Splendor” written by Harvey and illustrated by R.Crumb, he details the mundanities of ordinary life in such a way that makes for a great commentary on working class life in everyday America. The film covers the period of Harvey’s life when he gets divorced, looses his voice and compulsively collects old jazz records, to the time when he meets his new wife (Hope Davis), goes on the “Letterman” show to promote the comic, gets cancer and goes on to be part of this film. Cleverly realised we traverse his life via comics and actors, as well as interjections from the real Harvey, making an “ordinary life” quite compelling viewing.

results.title: American psycho [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Columbia Tristar, Edward Pressman and Mary Harron
results.brief_description: Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) is a highly successful Wall street businessman. He is a prime example of the opulence that flourished during the excessive consumerism of the 1980’s. Everything has its place and there is a place for everything, everything that is except Patrick’s mental stability. Call it a nervous breakdown or psychosis, his soul is simply not there. Combining horror, suspense and extremely dry satire, “American Psycho” is a meditation on excess and the loss of personal identity. Considering the controversial nature of Bret Easton Ellis’s novel, director Mary Harron and co-script writer Guinevere Turner have transliterated the work with remarkable wit and insight. The film maintains the ambiguous balance between what may be a horrific reality or an elaborate fantasy of a desperately lost soul. Cast also includes Willem Dafoe, Jared Leto, Chloe Sevigny and Reese Witherspoon.

results.title: American history X (D)
results.creator_credit: New Line Cinema, Turman-Morrissey Company, John Morriseey and Tony Kaye
results.brief_description: Rage vented as racism. Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton) seeks retribution for his father’s murder, and through his distorted logic and his charismatic leadership qualities, commands a growing army of skinheads at Venice Beach, California. Nobody looks up to Derek as much as his younger brother Danny (Edward Furlong), despite the efforts of his mother and teacher to persuade him otherwise. What should have been a case of self-defence, Derek violently attacks and murders an African American attempting to break into his car. After spending 3 years in prison, everyone awaits his return; his gang, his violent girlfriend and his younger brother. But Derek no longer shares the same views he once embraced as a badge of honour. What follows is a race to save his Danny and his family from the violence he’d brought down on so many others. Script by David McKenna.

results.title: American graffiti [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lucasfilm, Ltd., Coppola Co Productions, Francis Ford Coppola, Gary Kurtz and George Lucas
results.brief_description: This film from the director of the “Star Wars” trilogy is one of the most popular films of the 1970’s. The misadventures of four Californian teenagers on a late summer night in 1962, two of whom are leaving for college the next day, became the focal point for a trip back to the last “innocent” year of the 1960’s. Features a fine group of young actors who went on to become cinema and TV favourites, including Ron Howard, Richard Dreyfuss and Cindy Williams. The soundtrack features nostalgic hits from the heyday of Rock’n’Roll which takes the viewer back to a more innocent era when life was a lot less complicated. Don’t miss the great cameo appearance from Harrison Ford in the “toughest” role of his career.

results.title: American gigolo
results.creator_credit: Pierre Associates, Paramount Pictures, Jerry Bruckheimer and Paul Schrader
results.brief_description: Julian Kay is a suave, confident gigolo working for upper class older women in the LA area. Materialistic and refined Julian likes to think that he is above the seedy milieu of johns and blackmailers that inhabit his world. One night he is hired to service a woman whilst her husband watches - when she turns up dead shortly afterwards, Julian is suspected of murder. Meanwhile, Julian has become involved with Michelle Stratton, a beautiful woman unhappily married to a local senator. Michelle, who doesn’t pay for his services, is drawn to Julian, despite his occupation and seeks to assist him with his dilemma. This film in part addresses the sexual frustrations of middle-aged housewives whose husbands bore them and neglect their needs. But mostly it is an erotic thriller and a paean to the early 1980s - the clothes, music, cars and pre-AIDS hedonism. Directed by Paul Schrader (Cat people, Light sleeper, Affliction), “American gigolo” made a star of Richard Gere and was an early hit for Jerry Bruckheimer who went on to produce “Flashdance,” “Beverly Hills cop,” “Top gun” and “Pearl Harbour,” among others. Cast also includes Lauren Hutton, Hector Elizondo, Nina Van Pallandt.

results.title: Amateur
results.creator_credit: UGC Images, Zenith Entertainment, True Fiction Pictures, Ted Hope and Hal Hartley
results.brief_description: A quirky and absurdist comic thriller from writer/director, Hal Hartley. Isabelle (Isabelle Huppert) is an ex-nun awaiting an expected mission from God while making a living writing stories for pornographic magazines. She meets the kind and confused Thomas (Martin Donovan), who is suffering from amnesia and wandering the streets of New York in search of clues to his past, a past of viciousness and exploitation that only the appearance of his traumatized porn queen ex-wife, Sophia (Elina Lowensohn), begins to unravel. Intertwined with suspenseful thriller qualities and the subtlety of an unlikely romance, this film quietly spirals into a poignant tale of the pursuit of the reality of identity through memory and engagement with the past which leads sensitively to the inevitable tragedy of the final showdown.

results.title: Amadeus
results.creator_credit: Saul Zaentz Company, Saul Zaentz and Milos Forman
results.brief_description: A brilliant film version of a play on the life and death of Mozart, filmed in Prague and boasting one of the most literate film scripts of the 1980s. The story revolves around the unpleasant rivalry between Salieri and Mozart - musical mediocrity and genius respectively. Based on the play by Peter Shaffer. Cast includes Tom Hulce as Mozart and F. Murray Abraham as Salieri.

results.title: Altered states
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Howard Gottfried and Ken Russell
results.brief_description: William Hurt is Dr. Eddie Jessup, a scientist obsessed with the most enigmatic of questions: What is God? What is consciousness? How did life begin? His research leads him to experiments with sensory deprivation, schizophrenia, and finally with Native American hallucinogenic drugs which have been used in religious ritual for eons. As his experiments progress Eddie finds himself regressing further into the primordial past and bringing it back into his present. Ken Russell directs with his own hallucinogenic urgency, creating a pop fusion of horror film, psychedelic religiosity, existentialism and sheer knuckle-biting suspense. Wildly misunderstood on its release, “Altered States” is a fascinating movie roller-coaster grounded by a devilish sense of humour which refuses to allow the film to drift into pomposity or kant: this is Frankenstein on LSD. Blair Brown is Dr. Jessup’s equally brilliant but despairing wife. The enigmatic, frightening music score is by renowned composer John Corigliano.

results.title: Alphaville
results.creator_credit: Athos Film, Pathe Films, Andre Michelin and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description: A secret agent, posing as a journalist, from the ‘the world without’, penetrates ‘the world within’ - Alphaville. In his version of a futuristic dystopia, Jean-Luc Godard embraces a tech-noir aesthetic where human beings have become robotic slaves to technology, deprived of individuality and independent thought. In “Alphaville” the hero, played by Eddie Constantine with an embittered edge, evoking the ghost of Philipe Marlowe, has a mission to eliminate an eminent professor, the inventor of Alpha 60, a superior computer that governs society. The professor’s daughter, Natasha, played with an alluringly demure sensuality by Anna Karina, is the detective’s guide and also his love interest as he negotiates the bizarre, totalitarian state. Godard’s narrative is littered with numerous references, in particular, Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” and George Orwell’s “1984”. Godard uses the modernist 1960 Paris aesthetic to great effect, succeeding in presenting the city as a glimmering, ominous prison, where absurd and inhumane policies intermingle. Several memorable sequences include a firing squad - a cultural performance, accompanied by elegant water ballet sequences - that is witnessed by an admiring audience. An unusual addition to the canon of French New Wave cinema. Glorious black and white cinematography by Raoul Coutard. In French with English subtitles.

The professor’s daughter, Natasha, played with an alluringly demure sensuality by Anna Karina, is the detective’s guide and also his love interest as he negotiates the bizarre, totalitarian state. Godard’s narrative is littered with numerous references, in particular, Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” and George Orwell’s “1984”. Godard uses the modernist 1960 Paris aesthetic to great effect, succeeding in presenting the city as a glimmering, ominous prison, where absurd and inhumane policies intermingle. Several memorable sequences include a firing squad - a cultural performance, accompanied by elegant water ballet sequences - that is witnessed by an admiring audience. An unusual addition to the canon of French New Wave cinema. Glorious black and white cinematography by Raoul Coutard. In French with English subtitles.
